raw_text:
US bank 'loses' customer details
 
 The Bank of America has revealed it has lost computer tapes containing account details of more than one million customers who are US federal employees.
 
 Several members of the US Senate are among those affected, who could now be vulnerable to identity theft. Senate sources say the missing tapes may have been stolen from a plane by baggage handlers. The bank gave no details of how the records disappeared, but said they had probably not been misused. Customers' accounts were being monitoring and account holders would be notified if any "unusual activity" was detected, bank officials said.
 
 Bank of America said the tapes went missing in December while being shipped to a back-up data centre. "We, with federal law authorities, have done a very robust, thorough investigation on this and neither we nor they would make the statement lightly that we believe those tapes to be lost," Alexandra Tower, a spokeswoman for the North Carolina-based bank, told Time magazine. But although there was no evidence of criminal activity, the bank said, the Secret Service - a federal agency whose brief includes investigations of serious financial crime - is said to be looking into the loss. New York Senator Charles Schumer said he was told by the Senate Rules Committee that the tapes were probably stolen from a commercial plane. "Whether it is identity theft, terrorism, or other theft, in this new complicated world baggage handlers should have background checks and more care should be taken for who is hired for these increasingly sensitive positions," the Democrat senator said. Details of his Vermont colleague Pat Leahy's credit card account are among those missing, Senator Leahy's spokeswoman Tracy Schmaler said. About 900,000 military and civilian staff at the defence department are among the 1.2 million affected, according to a Pentagon spokesman.
llama3.2:1b: US bank Bank of America has lost computer tapes containing account details of over one million customers who are US federal employees. The tapes went missing in December while being shipped to a back-up data centre and have not been misused or stolen by individuals. However, the Secret Service is investigating the loss. The incident highlights concerns about security and background checks for individuals hired with sensitive positions.

The bank says no evidence suggests criminal misuse but is cooperating with the Secret Service investigation. The affected include 900,000 military and civilian staff at the defense department.

US bank 'loses' employee accounts  
The Bank of America has revealed it has lost computer tapes containing account details for over a million US federal employees. Several U.S. Senate members are among those affected, who could now be vulnerable to identity theft. The missing tapes might have been stolen from a plane by baggage handlers. Customers’ accounts were being monitored and account holders would be notified if any unusual activity was detected. Bank officials said the tapes went missing in December while being shipped to a backup data center. They confirmed that neither the bank nor federal law authorities would make lightly believed statements regarding their loss, though the Secret Service is investigating this as linked to more complex financial crimes. Specific examples include Pat Leahy's credit card and several from the defense department.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US bank, Bank of America, has reportedly lost computer tapes containing sensitive account details of more than one million federal employees and US citizens who were travelling or working in the Department of Defence. The missing tapes may have been stolen from a commercial plane while being shipped to a backup data centre. According to Senate sources, the tapes went missing in December, and bank officials stated that they had conducted a "robust" investigation into the loss, with neither the bank nor federal authorities believing there was any criminal activity involved. The missing tapes included details of Bank of America customers' credit cards, as well as information about their accounts at the Department of Defence, including employee numbers and account holder names. A report by Time magazine claimed that bank officials stated that the tapes went missing in December while being shipped to a backup data centre. Senator Charles Schumer stated that it was "likely" that baggage handlers were responsible for the tapes' loss, while Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell said that employees of the US Defence Department should undergo background checks and be provided with additional protection. The report noted that details of 1.2 million military and civilian staff at the Dept of Defense are also missing, and that the affected individuals included over 900,000 employees and more than one million civilians in the US federal government who were traveling or working for US Citizens.
